musicalLanguage.description: From the 1959 film Black Orpheus, this haunting bossa nova in A minor is one of the most beloved Brazilian compositions. The melody has a wistful, singing quality that moves through the natural and harmonic minor scales. The chord progression features the classic ii-V-i jazz pattern applied to bossa nova, creating a sophisticated but deeply emotional piece.
musicalLanguage.structure: A section: Am-Bm7b5-E7-Am descent (4 bars), B section: Dm7-G7-Cmaj7 relative major excursion (4 bars)
keyMoments: Bar 1: Am — the opening melody rises like a morning in Rio.
Bars 3-4: E7 to Am — the ii-V-i resolution in minor. The G# gives it bite.
Bars 5-6: Dm7 to G7 to Cmaj7 — briefly touching the relative major. A ray of sunlight.
teachingGoals: Minor key bossa nova feel — different from major bossa
ii-V-i chord progression in minor keys
Navigating between relative minor and major
styleTips: More melancholy than Girl from Ipanema — keep the minor color present
The melody should float but with a hint of sadness
Bossa rhythm stays gentle even when the harmony gets dark

measures.teachingNote: Am — ascending melody. Morning light through a window.

measures.leftHand: B2:q D3 F3 A3:q B2:q D3 F3 A3:q
measures.teachingNote: Bm7b5 — the ii chord in minor. G# hints at the coming E7.

measures.leftHand: E2:q G#3 B3 D4:q E2:q G#3 B3 D4:q
measures.teachingNote: E7 — dominant tension. G# is the leading tone pulling to A.
Am — resolution. Let the half notes breathe.

measures.leftHand: D3:q F3 A3 C4:q D3:q F3 A3 C4:q
measures.teachingNote: Dm7 — stepping toward the relative major. Warmth enters.

measures.leftHand: G2:q B3 D4 F4:q C2:q E3 G3 B3:q
measures.teachingNote: G7 to Cmaj7 — the major resolution. A brief moment of sunlight.

measures.leftHand: F2:q A3 C4 E4:q B2:q D3 F3 A3:q
measures.teachingNote: Fmaj7 to Bm7b5 — heading back to minor. The shadow returns.
E7 to Am — final resolution. The melody descends to rest.
